title: Experts Say THIS is the Best Robo Advisor!

transcript.text:
Robo-advisors like Betterment, Wealthfront, 
Vanguard, and Schwab now manage over $2 trillion

in assets. Maybe you're using one of these 
services and you're wondering if it's worth paying

for. Are you leaving money on the table? Which 
of these robo-advisors is best? What does robo

mean anyway? Today's presentation is chock full of 
information about robo-advisors that you need to

know. So, we've been covering robo-advisors now 
for over a decade. We've even worked with some

of them in the past. And the name robo-advisor 
implies some sort of AI usage when that's actually

not really the case. The recipe-driven approach 
that most robo-advisers take is quite simple. You

may be familiar with the 100 minus your age rule. 
That simply says that you take 100 minus your age

and that's how much money you ought to have in 
equities and the rest in bonds. As time goes on,

of course, as you age, the ratio of money going 
into bonds increases. That's often called a glide

path. And what you're doing there is you're 
gradually shifting your asset allocation from

more risky assets to less risky assets, bonds, 
over time. As you get closer to retirement,

you want to reduce volatility. So a robo-advisor 
roughly does the same thing. It automatically

configures your allocations as you age. And 
the real value ad for robo-advisors was that

they were going to be a lower fee alternative 
to human advisors. This table here was actually

taken from a piece that we did. I think this was 
eight years ago looking at robo-advisors AI and

asset allocation. And we had made the remark here 
that these are really the same sort of tools that

private wealth managers use except now they're 
stuffed into the cloud and automated so that

anybody can access them. And when we think about 
the $2 trillion that robo-advisers are managing,

it's always important to put numbers into context. 
So whilst that sounds very large, it actually

isn't. So when you look at global assets under 
management, so this would be money that's being

managed by third parties, the value of that is 
now close to $150 trillion. So robo-advisors

manage about 2 trillion. That's about the same 
amount of money that Edward Jones manages.

However, it's less than 2% of total wealth being 
managed. However, if you multiply that, let's say,

by 30 basis points, perhaps the average fee being 
charged by a robo adviser, you get a run rate of

about $6 billion. So, there's a lot of money to 
be made there. And we can look at this report

by Morningstar, which looks at robo-advisors in 
2025. The executive summary here talks about how

the great robo-advisor disruption never arrived. 
So, it was anticipated that robo-advisors would

replace human advisers. Well, that never really 
worked out. And this is pretty remarkable here.

It says just one pure robo-advisor remains that 
does not offer some person-to-person counsel with

its algorithmic guidance. What this ended up 
turning into is really just a lead magnet to

attract assets so that then they can upsell their 
clients personal advisor services. So really,

we've just gone full circle and Morningstar 
here talks about how for young investors with

uncomplicated financial situations, robo-advisors 
can be good starting places. Well, not when you

have an environment now fueled by fintwats and 
social media where everybody's pushed towards

high-risk options and prediction markets and 
things like that. So whilst it may be good for

young investors, I don't think a lot of them are 
availing themselves of these tools. And when you

look at a robo-advisor like Betterment here, you 
can see they're talking about how self-directed

investing is here. Again, going full circle. 
The idea was that it wouldn't be self-directed,

that you would let these algorithms dictate your 
asset allocation. And now they're saying, well,

you can be self-directed. They're really trying 
to be everything to everyone. And that sort of

defeats the original purpose of robo-advisors. 
And here I've provided a table generated by Grok,

which looks at the top robo-advisor by assets 
under management. And there's a couple takeaways

here. So, first of all, you're going to get 
different numbers depending on where you look,

but the leader by far would be Vanguard. 
Rather remarkable. $333 billion in assets

under management. And of course, they offer some 
of the lowest fees out there. You would expect

that from Vanguard. That's their reputation, 
low fees, right? Then you have Schwab here. Now,

Schwab's done a great job of offering a lot 
of low-fee products, but they talk about here,

no advisory fee. Well, there's no 
such thing as a free lunch, right? So,

we're going to look into that. And then there's 
Wealthfront, which is actually having an IPO. And

that gives us an inside look into the mechanics 
of a robo-advisor, and we're going to talk about

whether or not that would be something you'd 
want to invest in. So, when we look at Schwab,

you see here, no advisory fee charge. They 
compare themselves to other robo-advisors.

And then when you dig into the mechanics, of 
course, you complete these questionnaires so

they can assess your risk tolerance. It also takes 
into account your age. And then you're given a

diversified portfolio of ETFs. Well, those ETFs, 
of course, are charging fees. So there is no such

thing as a free lunch. And when you look at the 
assessment of Schwab's offering by Morningstar,

this is rather interesting. So technically, Schwab 
could not charge fees at all and simply make money

on the cash that they're holding. And they talk 
here about how Schwab's intelligent portfolios

make excessive cash allocations. You need 
to be careful there because there's a lot

of incentive for Schwab to hold that cash. And 
we're going to look at why that is when we take

a closer look at Wealthfront, which realizes 75% 
of their revenues coming off of cash management.

And they talk here about how cash can be a drag on 
returns. Well, really, when it comes to returns,

this is a moot point. You need to focus on 
fees. So when you look at this collateral here,

I think this is from Betterment talking about how 
since they launched their core portfolio, it's

delivered over 9%. Yeah. So roughly what the stock 
market has delivered. That's what you expect,

right? You provided market performance. So what? 
That's what your clients would expect. So, when

you're looking to choose a robo-advisor, don't 
pay attention to what they say their performance

is. Focus on fee structures, which will differ 
by account sizes. So, typically the larger the

account, the smaller the fees that you're paying. 
But remember that the company managing the most

assets is going to have the most flexibility when 
it comes to offering the lowest fees. And that's

Vanguard. They've built their entire brand based 
on being the lowcost leader. It's no surprise at

all that they're ranked highest by Morningstar. 
I think three out of the past four years they've

been ranked highest. But I noticed the footnote 
was quite interesting. They said, compensation

provided for use of the rating and marketing 
materials. So Morningstar rates them and then

they have to pay Morningstar to put that in their 
market materials. It's rather shifty, but I think

when you read this report by Morningstar, it all 
makes sense. It comes down to fees. So, what you

can do is go over to Vanguard's site and calculate 
the cost or they don't call it a robo-advisor

anymore. They call it a digital advisor. You 
plug in the amount of money that you're going

to invest in it. It tells you what you're going 
to pay. So, I would say if you're going to pay

20 basis points for an asset allocation glide path 
of the type that Vanguard is providing, just do it

yourself with Fidelity Zero products and don't 
pay any fees at all. A major reason why people

have financial advisors is for emotional support. 
This was taken from a piece we did that looked at

financial advisors and why people hire them. 
And emotion-based reasons make up the majority

of reasons why they're being hired. And that's 
because when the stock market starts crashing

or a stock starts falling, that's when everybody 
starts asking questions. Whenever there's a market

correction, we get inundated with emails from 
people who want assurance. They get that from

financial advisors. One would hope they do, right? 
You should stay the course. That's typically what

a financial adviser would tell you. So, what you 
can do then is pay Vanguard a little bit extra

and get a personal advisor. So, you should always 
be looking at fees that you're paying, divided by

the money that you're giving them. So, simple math 
shows that for a personal adviser, you have to,

I think, have at least 50k. That's going to be 
35 basis points. That's reasonable. Compare that

to Edward Jones, which is going to charge you 1% 
upfront. And then, of course, hefty fees on the

products that they push you towards. Right? What 
I really like about this is it explains it very

clearly. The most you'll pay. And then when you 
look at the mechanics here, well, they're saying,

"All right, we're going to refund the fees 
that you're paying for the products we push you

towards." And that goes against that fee. So the 
most you're ever going to pay is 35 basis points.

Now, when it comes to the future of robo-advisors, 
it doesn't look all that promising to be honest.

I like this timeline that can be found in that 
Morningstar report and it looks at the various

large firms out there that dabbled. What's 
remarkable is it took less than six years for

Vanguard to simply dominate this space. So, back 
when we first started looking at robo-advisors,

they weren't even playing, and now they're by 
far the biggest leader. Took Goldman five years,

less than 5 years, to decide robo-advisors 
weren't for them. JP Morgan also shuttered their

offering on weak demand. So that brings us to the 
Wealthfront IPO. So this was announced, I think,

in September, and only recently got around to 
looking at the S1. Not missing a whole lot,

but certainly some interesting information here. 
So first of all, they talk about $88 billion in

assets under management. Well, that's different 
from the numbers we looked at before, and that's

because they're breaking out cash management from 
investment advisory fees. So, if we take the money

they're managing, $42 billion, we multiply that by 
25 bips, we get $105 million. Well, when we look

at their actual revenues, investment advisory is 
a lot less. But here is what's remarkable. Cash

management makes up 75% of their revenues. So, 
the lion's share of money they're making comes

from interest that they're receiving from cash 
balances that they're holding for their clients.

So this is potentially problematic. So if they 
shift that from cash management to investments,

presumably they're going to make less. But 
what will really have them making less is

when interest rates continue to drop. So this 
doesn't bode well for their business. When we

look at the future of robo-advisors, I think 
Morningstar says it best. Few digital advisers,

robo-advisors, whatever you want to call 
them, rely solely on computer algorithms.

They're now starting to look more like the firms 
that they were trying to disrupt. Again, we're

coming full circle. Nearly all digital advisers 
now offer some human counsel, but they continue to

compete on cost and new features. So, that's good 
for customers. Morningstar says that none of these

digital advisers foresee using AI to generate 
recommendations yet because they're fearful of

things like hallucinations. But when you consider 
that this is simply an asset allocation exercise,

how much real value is AI going to add anyway? So 
this conclusion, of course, that digital advisers,

robo advisers have supplemented rather than 
supplanted traditional advisor. So the big

question, should you use a robo-advisor? Well, if 
you can't be asked to deal with asset allocation

decisions yourself, then sure. But if you don't 
need human contact, just create your own glide

path using Fidelity Zero. And think long and hard 
about paying for human contact. How often are you

going to use that, right? So make sure that you're 
getting, as we talked about in our financial

advisor piece, you're getting sufficient value and 
you understand all the fees you're paying. That's

why we like Vanguard, right? Transparency. They're 
the only robo-adviser we would consider. So they

have the assets under management to truly compete 
on price. Their fee structure is transparent with

this will-not-exceed structure. Also, this isn't 
a binary decision. You could allocate some of your

assets to a robo-advisor and then use that as a 
benchmark. Now, when it comes to Wealthfront's

IPO, I don't think investing in that seems like 
a great idea. Remains to be seen what the stock

price does, but the company isn't attractive for 
the reasons that we talked about. What happens

when interest rates fall? So, I'm sure a fair 
number of you out there have financial advisors.

I think it's very important that you understand 
the value that you're getting. So, you ought to

watch this piece next. It's probing the sort of 
questions you ought to be asking your financial

advisor. So, give that a watch next. Thanks so 
much for taking the time to watch this today.
